title: Worker Practices
description: Worker hygiene and practices requirements including handwashing compliance, prohibited activities in production areas, jewelry restrictions, illness reporting, visitor controls, and personal hygiene standards

requirements.text: Are workers washing and sanitizing their hands before starting work each day, after using the restroom, after breaks, before putting on gloves and whenever hands may be contaminated?
mandatoryStatements: Workers must wash and sanitize hands before starting work each day
Handwashing required after using restroom facilities and after breaks
Hands must be washed before putting on gloves
Handwashing required whenever hands may become contaminated
Proper handwashing technique must be followed for minimum 20 seconds
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily observation of handwashing compliance at critical moments, quarterly handwashing effectiveness audits
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous supervisory observation of handwashing compliance, immediate correction of non-compliance

requirements.text: Are workers' fingernails clean, short and free of nail polish?
mandatoryStatements: Fingernails must be kept clean and trimmed short
Nail polish and artificial nails are prohibited
Pre-shift inspections must verify fingernail condition
Nail cleaning brushes must be provided at handwashing stations
Workers unable to maintain standards must wear gloves
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily pre-shift fingernail inspections documented, weekly spot checks during operations
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Visual inspection during pre-shift checks, immediate correction required for non-compliance

requirements.text: Are workers who are working directly or indirectly with food, without evidence of boils, sores, open wounds and are not exhibiting signs of foodborne illness?
mandatoryStatements: Workers with boils, sores, or open wounds must be excluded from food handling
Workers exhibiting illness symptoms must be excluded
Illness reporting policy must be established and communicated
Health screening must be conducted at start of shift
Medical clearance required before return to work after illness
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily health screening of all workers, monthly review of illness reporting compliance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Pre-shift health checks for all workers, immediate exclusion of ill or wounded workers

requirements.text: Are workers wearing effective hair restraints that contain all hair?
mandatoryStatements: All workers in food production areas must wear effective hair restraints
Hair restraints must fully contain all head and facial hair
Beard nets required for workers with facial hair
Pre-shift inspection must verify proper hair restraint use
Hair restraints must be worn at all times in production areas
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily pre-shift verification of hair restraint compliance, weekly observations during production
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous visual monitoring of hair restraint compliance, immediate correction of violations

requirements.text: Are workers not observed wearing watches, jewelry (plain band permitted), studs, false eyelashes, false fingernails, etc.?
mandatoryStatements: Jewelry, watches, false eyelashes, and false fingernails are prohibited
Only plain wedding bands are permitted
Pre-shift inspection must verify no prohibited items
Lockers must be provided for storage of personal items
Progressive discipline for repeated violations
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily pre-shift inspection documented, weekly compliance audits during operations
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Visual verification during pre-shift checks, continuous observation for compliance

requirements.text: Are all workers wearing protective outer garments suitable for the operation (e.g., appropriate clean clothes, smocks, aprons, sleeves, non-latex gloves)?
mandatoryStatements: Workers must wear clean protective outer garments appropriate to their work areas
Smocks, aprons, sleeves, and gloves must be provided as needed
Non-latex gloves preferred to prevent allergen concerns
Garments must be clean at start of shift
Daily garment inspection and exchange program must be implemented
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily verification of garment cleanliness and suitability, weekly garment condition assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Pre-shift inspection of protective garments, continuous observation for garment condition

requirements.text: Do workers remove protective outer garments (e.g., smocks, aprons, sleeves, and gloves) when on break, before using the toilets and when going home at the end of their shift?
mandatoryStatements: Protective garments must be removed before using toilet facilities
Garments must be removed during breaks
Garments must be removed at end of shift
Designated storage areas must be provided for removed garments
Signage must remind workers to remove garments
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly observation of garment removal compliance, monthly training reinforcement
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Supervisory monitoring at break rooms and restroom entries, immediate correction of violations

requirements.text: Is there a designated area for workers to leave protective outer garments (e.g., smocks, aprons, sleeves, and gloves) when on break and before using the toilets?
mandatoryStatements: Designated areas must be provided for garment storage during breaks and restroom use
Storage areas must prevent garment contact with contamination sources
Adequate hooks or racks must be provided
Storage areas must be located adjacent to break rooms and restrooms
Storage areas must be kept clean and organized
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly inspection of designated garment storage areas for adequacy and cleanliness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification that designated storage areas are being used properly

requirements.text: Are worker personal items being stored in such a way that they are not a potential food safety risk to product, equipment or materials?
mandatoryStatements: Personal belongings must be stored in designated areas separate from production zones
Lockers or storage facilities must be provided outside production areas
Personal items prohibited in production areas
Phones, bags, and personal food must be stored in lockers
Regular inspections must verify no personal items in production areas
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly audit of locker facilities and compliance, weekly production area inspections for personal items
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification that personal items are not in production areas, immediate removal if found

requirements.text: Is smoking, eating, chewing and drinking confined to designated areas, and spitting is prohibited in all areas?
mandatoryStatements: Eating, drinking (except water), smoking, and chewing restricted to designated break areas
Spitting is strictly prohibited throughout all facility areas
Designated areas must be clearly marked and separated from production
Drinking water allowed only from designated clean sources
Policy must be communicated and enforced
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly compliance audits, quarterly policy communication verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous supervisory monitoring for violations, immediate enforcement action

requirements.text: Is fresh potable drinking water in clean containers readily accessible to workers?
mandatoryStatements: Fresh potable drinking water must be readily accessible to all workers
Water must be provided in clean, covered containers or fountains
Single-use cups must be provided if using communal containers
Water sources must be maintained in sanitary condition
Adequate number of water access points for workforce size
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily verification of water availability and container cleanliness, monthly water quality testing
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Multiple daily checks of water availability and cleanliness, immediate refilling and cleaning as needed

requirements.text: Are all items removed from garment (shirt, blouse, etc.) top pockets, and unsecured items are not worn (e.g., pens, glasses on top of the head, Bluetooth devices, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Items must be removed from shirt and apron pockets
Pens, tools, and thermometers must be securely attached or stored
Glasses, Bluetooth devices, and unsecured items must not be worn on head
Pocketless garments or secured pocket flaps preferred
Pre-shift inspection must verify no unsecured items
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily pre-shift inspection for unsecured items, weekly compliance audits
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Visual verification during pre-shift checks, continuous observation for loose items

requirements.text: Are first aid kits adequately stocked and readily available to workers in the facility, and are blue band aids used?
mandatoryStatements: First aid kits must be adequately stocked and readily accessible
Blue-colored or metal-detectable bandages must be used
Kits must include antiseptic, gloves, and related supplies
Monthly inspections must verify kit completeness
Kit locations must be posted on facility maps
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly first aid kit inspection and restocking, quarterly kit location adequacy assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly verification of kit accessibility and blue bandage availability, immediate restocking as needed

mandatoryStatements: Workers must wash and sanitize hands thoroughly before starting work, after using restroom facilities, after breaks, before putting on gloves, and whenever hands may become contaminated during work activities
Worker fingernails must be kept clean, trimmed short, and free of nail polish or artificial nails that could harbor bacteria or become foreign material hazards

Workers with boils, sores, open wounds, or exhibiting symptoms of foodborne illness (diarrhea, vomiting, fever, jaundice, sore throat with fever) must be excluded from food handling areas and reported to management
All workers in food production areas must wear effective hair restraints (hairnets, caps, beard nets as applicable) that fully contain all head and facial hair to prevent contamination

Workers must not wear jewelry, watches, false eyelashes, or false fingernails in food production areas; only plain wedding bands are permitted to minimize foreign material and bacterial harborage risks
Workers must wear clean protective outer garments appropriate to their work areas including smocks, aprons, sleeves, and gloves (non-latex preferred) that are suitable for the specific operation
Protective outer garments must be removed before using toilet facilities, during breaks, and at the end of shifts to prevent transfer of contamination between production and non-production areas
Designated areas must be provided for workers to properly hang or store protective garments when removed for breaks or restroom use, preventing garment contact with contamination sources
Worker personal belongings including phones, bags, medications, and food items must be stored in designated areas separate from production zones to prevent food safety contamination risks
Eating, drinking (except water), smoking, and chewing (gum, tobacco) must be restricted to designated break areas; spitting is strictly prohibited throughout all facility areas
Fresh potable drinking water must be readily accessible to all workers in clean, covered containers or fountains with single-use cups to maintain hydration without contamination risks

Items such as pens, thermometers, phones, and tools must not be stored in shirt or apron pockets; glasses, Bluetooth devices, and other unsecured items must not be worn on head or loosely attached where they could fall into products

First aid kits must be adequately stocked with supplies including blue-colored bandages (for detectability), antiseptic, gloves, and related items; kits must be readily accessible and regularly inspected for completeness
capaInject: When inadequate handwashing practices are observed, immediately enforce handwashing requirements with direct supervision, install additional signage in multiple languages at handwashing stations, implement observation programs with documented compliance verification, and provide refresher training on proper handwashing technique and critical timing

If workers have improper fingernail condition, immediately provide nail clippers and cleaning brushes at entry points, establish pre-shift inspection procedures with documented verification, implement policies requiring glove use for workers who cannot maintain acceptable nail standards, and enforce disciplinary measures for repeated violations

Upon identifying workers with health conditions or illness symptoms, immediately exclude them from food handling areas, refer to occupational health services for assessment, establish a written illness reporting and exclusion policy with clear criteria, train supervisors on symptom recognition, and maintain confidential health records

When hair restraint violations are observed, immediately provide proper hair restraints, establish pre-shift inspection stations with documented compliance checks, install mirrors at entry points for self-inspection, require beard nets for workers with facial hair, and implement progressive discipline for non-compliance

If jewelry or prohibited items are observed, immediately require removal and storage in lockers, establish clear written policies on permitted and prohibited items, conduct pre-shift inspections with documented verification, provide storage for items removed during shift, and enforce consistent disciplinary actions

For inadequate or unsuitable protective garments, immediately provide appropriate clean garments, establish daily garment inspection and exchange programs, implement color-coding by department or task, ensure adequate inventory of all sizes, and establish laundering or disposal procedures to maintain garment cleanliness

When workers fail to remove garments before breaks or restroom use, install signage reminding workers to remove garments, establish designated garment storage areas adjacent to break rooms and restrooms, implement observation programs with supervisory enforcement, and provide training emphasizing cross-contamination prevention

If personal items pose food safety risks, immediately relocate items to designated storage areas, provide adequate locker facilities separate from production areas, prohibit phones and personal items in production zones, conduct routine inspections of production areas for personal items, and enforce storage policies through progressive discipline

When eating, drinking, or smoking violations occur in production areas, immediately stop the activity, reinforce designated area policies through signage and training, establish clear visual demarcation of permitted areas, implement supervisory monitoring programs, and enforce prohibition of spitting through training and discipline

If drinking water access is inadequate, immediately provide additional water stations with clean cups or covered coolers at convenient locations, establish daily cleaning and refilling schedules, ensure ice for coolers comes from potable sources, provide cups in dispensers preventing hand contact, and monitor water quality periodically

When unsecured items are found on workers, immediately require removal to lockers, provide pens, tools, and equipment that can be securely attached or stored in provided tool belts, establish policies requiring secured pocket flaps or use of pocketless garments, and conduct pre-shift inspections verifying compliance

If first aid kits are inadequately stocked or inaccessible, immediately restock all supplies, establish monthly inspection checklists with signed verification, ensure kits are located within specified distance of all work areas, post kit locations on facility maps, train designated first aid responders, and implement procedures requiring bandage color verification (blue) before restocking
traceabilityInject: Maintain handwashing observation records documenting compliance checks, critical handwashing moments verified, non-compliance observations, corrective actions taken, and trend analysis identifying problem areas or times

Keep pre-shift inspection logs documenting worker hygiene compliance including fingernail condition, hair restraints, jewelry, protective garments, and health status with corrective actions for non-conformances

Document illness reporting and exclusion records including worker symptoms, date reported, exclusion period, medical clearance for return to work, and confidential medical information in secure files separate from production records

Retain training records for worker hygiene practices showing training dates, topics covered (handwashing, personal hygiene, illness reporting), trainer identification, and worker verification of understanding

Maintain protective garment inventory and laundering records including garment distribution, cleaning schedules, garment condition inspections, and replacement activities ensuring adequate supply of clean garments

Keep records of personal storage facility inspections documenting locker availability, cleanliness, separation from production areas, and any findings of personal items in production zones with corrective actions

Document first aid kit inspection logs showing inspection date, inspector name, contents verification against standard list, items requiring restocking, blue bandage verification, and corrective actions completed

Retain incident reports for any hygiene-related product contamination events including investigation findings, worker practices involved, corrective actions implemented, and effectiveness verification to prevent recurrence
micro_inject: Inadequate handwashing is the primary transmission route for fecal-oral pathogens including E. coli O157:H7, Salmonella, Shigella, Hepatitis A virus, and Norovirus which collectively cause millions of foodborne illnesses annually

Fingernails harbor significantly higher bacterial loads than fingertips including Staphylococcus aureus, E. coli, and Salmonella; artificial nails and nail polish create additional surfaces for bacterial adhesion and biofilm formation that handwashing cannot effectively remove

Workers with boils or open wounds may be colonized with Staphylococcus aureus which can produce heat-stable enterotoxins in food products causing staphylococcal food poisoning; even after bacterial death, toxins remain active and dangerous

A single human hair can carry 50,000-100,000 bacteria including Staphylococcus species and potential pathogens from environmental sources; hair contamination is both a food safety hazard and quality defect with high consumer complaint potential

Jewelry and watches create crevices and surfaces that harbor bacteria and cannot be adequately cleaned through handwashing; studies show bacterial populations under rings can be 1000 times higher than on adjacent skin

Contaminated protective garments can serve as fomites transferring pathogens from restrooms, break areas, or outdoor environments into food production areas when workers fail to change or remove garments appropriately

Personal items including phones and bags frequently contact contaminated surfaces and can harbor pathogens; studies show mobile phones carry higher bacterial loads than toilet seats including MRSA, E. coli, and Salmonella

Eating, drinking, or smoking in production areas introduces saliva which may contain foodborne illness agents (Hepatitis A, Norovirus) and creates opportunities for hand-to-mouth contact followed by hand-to-food-product transfer without proper handwashing

Inadequate hydration access may discourage workers from drinking, leading to dehydration and potentially increased likelihood of fainting or decreased hygiene awareness; conversely, providing water in production areas creates contamination risks requiring controlled access points

Unsecured items falling from pockets or heads represent physical hazards in products and may carry biological contamination from environmental sources outside production areas where the items were previously handled or stored

Non-blue bandages that fall into products are difficult to detect visually and may not be captured by metal detectors or x-ray machines, allowing contamination to reach consumers; blue color provides contrast against most food products for visual detection

Wounds treated with contaminated first aid supplies or improperly protected with inadequate bandages continue to shed bacteria including antibiotic-resistant Staphylococcus aureus into the production environment
